abstract.para: This chapter describes Combustion‐the tool used to configure your system according to your configuration on first boot.

sect1.title: About Combustion
sect1.para: Combustion is a dracut module that enables you to configure your system on first boot. Combustion reads a provided script and executes commands in it and thus perform changes to the file system. You can use Combustion to change the default partitions, set users' passwords, create files, install packages, etc.

The Combustion dracut module is invoked after the ignition.firstboot argument is passed to the kernel command line. Combustion then reads configuration from script. Combustion tries to configure network, if the network flag has been found in script. After /sysroot is mounted, Combustion tries to activate all mountpoints in /etc/fstab and then call transactional-update to apply other changes (like setting &rootuser; password or installing packages).

When using Combustion, you need to label the configuration device combustion, create a specific directory structure on your configuration media and include a configuration file named script. sect1.para: If you want to log in to your system, include at least the &rootuser; password. Though it is recommend to establish the authentification using SSH keys. If you need to use a &rootuser; password, make sure to configure a secure password. In case you use a randomly generated password, use at least 10 characters. If you create your password manually, use even more than 10 characters and combine uppercase and lowecase letters, and numbers.
